geoDecl.note: No location. Daily weather report for the month of July 1805.

row.cell: wind hard during greater part of the day.—
some rain just before sun rise
heavy dew this morning. slight sprinkle of rain at 2 P. M.

heavy shower of rain and hail last evening at 9 P. M. some
thunder & L[ightning]

wind high all day. A heavy wind from the S. W. attended
with rain about the middle of the last night. about day had
a violent thunderstorm attended with Hail and rain. the
Hail Covered the ground and was about the Size of Mus-
quet balls. I have Seen only one black bird killed with the
hail, and am astonished that more have not Suffered in a
similar manner as they are abundant, and I Should Sup-
pose the hail Sufficiently heavy to kill them.
I finish taking the hight of the falls of the Missouri
Wind violent in the latter part of the day
Set out from our upper campabove the falls
I set out in Search of the Indians
Thunder Storm ½ after 3 P. M.
he sets out again this morning
Snow appears on the mountains ahead.

a considerable fall of rain unattended with Lightning. Capt
Clarkrejoins me

div.note: Lewishas weather notes for this month in Codex Fe and Codex P; Clark'sare in Codex I. This table follows Codex Fe, with discrepancies noted.
Lewisin Codex P and Clarkin Codex I have "56."
For this day Clarknotes that the river fell one-half inch.

The remarks follow Lewis'smarginal remarks in Codices Fe and P. Some of the remarks appear to be in Clark'shandwriting. Clarkhas some marginal remarks in Codex I, other than those he copied from Lewis, which are noted below.
Clarkin Codex I has, "everything across the portage."
The remainder of this entry is from a separate remark in Codices Fe and P.
Perhaps the common grackle, Quiscalus quiscula[AOU, 511], although other black birds are possible.
Clarkin Codex I has, "I took 8 men in Search of timber to build 2 canoes."
Clarkin Codex I has, "over taken by the party after being out [ blank] Days in Search of the Indians."
Clarkadds, "I join the party at the 3 forksverry Sick."
